block.p: Melissa Jo Fleming, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. Fleming of Spartanburg, S.C., was married there yesterday to Gregory Stephen Selch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Selch of New York. The Rev. Dr. Todd B. Jones performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

Mrs. Selch, 30, was until May the promotion director at Harper's Bazaar magazine in New York; she is now a freelance writer. She graduated from Smith College. Her father, a cardiologist, is a partner in Cardio Medical Associates in Spartanburg. Her mother, Elizabeth Fleming, is a member of the Spartanburg City Council.

Melissa Jo Fleming, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. Fleming of Spartanburg, S.C., was married there yesterday to Gregory Stephen Selch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Selch of New York. The Rev. Dr. Todd B. Jones performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

Mrs. Selch, 30, was until May the promotion director at Harper's Bazaar magazine in New York; she is now a freelance writer. She graduated from Smith College. Her father, a cardiologist, is a partner in Cardio Medical Associates in Spartanburg. Her mother, Elizabeth Fleming, is a member of the Spartanburg City Council.

Mr. Selch, 33, is a freelance photographer in New York. He graduated from Hamilton College. His mother, Patricia Bakwin Selch, is the chairwoman of the board of the Association in Manhattan for Autistic Children. His father, who retired as the editor and publisher of Ovation, the classical music magazine, is the director of the Center for the Study of American Music History in New York.

The bridegroom is a maternal great-great grandson of Gustavus Swift, the founder of Swift & Company, the Chicago meat-packing and stockyard company. His maternal grandparents, the late Dr. Ruth Bakwin and Dr. Harry Bakwin, were pediatricians in New York who wrote a well-regarded book on behavioral disorders in children and were collectors of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art.
